bug.short_desc: Changes to the Action or Expected Results section of Test Cases cause incorrect search behavior

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.14) Gecko/20080404 Firefox/2.0.0.14 Build Identifier: Testopia 2.0
Note that this was reported in the past for Testopia version 1.2 in bug 385477, but for the sake of helping the engineer who will fix it, I'm re-reporting and updating it as a new bug since, although the underlying issue remains, the symptoms in Testopia 2.0 are quite different. Once done, the old bug will be marked as a duplicate of this one.
It appears that the Test Case search tool is searching through old versions of Test Cases. When a change is committed to the Action or Expected Results section of a TC, the old Case Versions do not seem to be skipped by the search.
For instance, let's say that originally my Expected Results section for a test case has the sentence "The user is loggged in" (notice the typo in the word 'logged'), and I make a commit to correct the typo. Now, I do a search that looks for the word "user" in the Expected Results section. In this case, both versions are caught by the search tool and considered as if they are two separate hits when you look at the result count at the bottom right of the screen. If I make another change and then repeat the search, I will register as three separate hits, and so on.
The symptom described above is not so bad, since it's only the number of hits that is off, and you can get the right number simply by selecting "View All" in the results page (although it won't make sense, it will say something like "Display test cases 1 - 74 of 85" when there are no other pages). However, there is another more serious symptom that leads to inaccurate results and that I have not found any workaround for. Let's say for instance that the Expected Results field originally reads as follows "The server is logged in" where the word "server" was a mistake and should have been "user". I notice the mistake and correct it by changing the word "server" for "user" and committing the change. Now, if I do a TC search for the word "server" in the Expected Results section, the Test Case I fixed should not be returned, because the word has been removed. Due to this bug however, the test case will incorrectly be returned because the word used to be there in an old version.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a Test Case where the Action section is simply the following: "Apple Banana" 2. After the TC has been created, go back to it and delete the word "Banana" and commit the change. 3. Go to the Test Case Search page and look for the word "Apple" in the Action section. 4. Try again with the word "Banana"
Actual Results: 3. The test case is returned and the number of hits in the bottom right corner says "Displaying test cases 1 - 1 of 2" 4. The test case is incorrectly returned in the results.
Expected Results: 3. The test case is returned and the number of hits in the bottom right corner says "Displaying test cases 1 - 1 of 1" 4. No results are found because the word "Banana" is no longer in the Action section.
This makes creating batches of similar test cases with only a small change in them using the Clone feature a painful situation when it comes to searching through them later on. If I clone a test case 5 times and change one section each time, but then do a search for a term in the original section that was changed for all the rest, all 6 test cases are returned.
*** Bug 385477 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Search results are now set up with a DISTINCT so that no repeats should be appearing. However, I do not have a solution to the other problem of returning results when they match a previous version.
Here is the SQL: SELECT test_cases.case_id FROM test_cases LEFT JOIN test_case_texts AS case_texts ON (test_cases.case_id = case_texts.case_id) WHERE ((INSTR(CAST(LOWER(case_texts.action) AS BINARY), CAST('jellyfish' AS BINARY)) > 0))
The problem is that the test_case_texts are joined in a separate table (which is how multiple versions are kept). Anyone know how to essentially say WHERE case_text_version = MAX(case_text_version)?

What about something to this effect:
... WHERE case_text_version = (Select MAX(case_text_version) FROM test_cases t1 WHERE t1.case_id = test_cases.case_id)

bug.short_desc: Reordering lists by clicking column heading eliminates repeats

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.4) Gecko/20070515 Firefox/2.0.0.4 Build Identifier: 1.2
When looking at a list of items in a table view, such as the list of test cases in a test plan, or the search results from Testopia Search, the column heading a clickable, I'm assuming so that one can choose to reorder the list of items by that given column's criteria. If this is indeed the case, then the number of items in the list should not change. Only the order they are sorted in.
For instance, let's say you have the following list.
Item Color Family ------------------------- Apple Red Fruit Bear Brown Animal Orange Orange Fruit Tiger Orange Animal *4 records found
With the headings being clickable, as they are in Testopia lists, clicking on them should reorder the list and sort by that heading. In the previous example, clicking on "Family" would reorder the list as follows...
Item Color Family ------------------------- Bear Brown Animal Tiger Orange Animal Apple Red Fruit Orange Orange Fruit *4 records found
In Testopia however, duplicates of the chosen heading get thrown out. Clicking on the same heading from the previous example would therefore produce the following...
Item Color Family ------------------------- Bear Brown Animal Apple Red Fruit *2 records found
I don't believe this to be intended.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new Test Plan. 2. Create three Test Cases within this plan, with the first and third one being in the CONFIRMED status, and the second one in the PROPOSED status. 3. View the Test Plan and scroll down to the "Test Cases" section ==> The three Test Cases are listed in a table in ascending order of their Test Case ID 4. Click on the "Status" heading Actual Results: The list gets cut down from three to two... one with status CONFIRMED and one with status PROPOSED. The second CONFIRMED Test Case has been removed from the list
Expected Results: The same three Test Cases are still listed, this time in ascending order of their status. Test Cases with the same status (in this case, the two that are CONFIRMED) are grouped together.
I see this using both Firefox 2.0.0.4 and Internet Exporer 7.0
Fixed

bug.short_desc: Test case: "Effect" is unclear name for "Expected outcomes" or "Success condition"

long_desc.thetext:
(from manual: Test Case: Fields: Effect)
One of the most important fields of a test case is how to determine whether the test has passed.
Performing a test may have many "effects" that are not the subject of the test (maybe they are tested by previous tests, or maybe they are effects of an underlying library not under test). Need a term that focuses the test-writer's attention on the subject of the test.
Performing a test may succeed or fail with different outcomes. "Effects" may be interpreted as a request for a table of all possible outcomes. Since most tests can fail in innumerable ways, prefer a term that focuses the test-writer's attention on determining that the test succeeded.
"Effects" may also be understood in some contexts as meaning "side effects", i.e., changes in state, I/O, etc. as opposed to a value returned by a function with no (side) effects. Need a term that covers all changes and outcomes: effects, results, exceptions, etc.
"Expected outcomes" is a title that focuses on the test writer on producing samples of what to expect in the successful case, for the test runner to match, such as string value, or an image of a web page. But not all tests produce easily matched outcomes, so sometimes it is better to provide a procedure.
"Success condition" is a title that focuses the test writer on producing description of procedure to test a condition, such as a balance that depends on the starting balance, or a uid that is different from a previous uid.

These are very good suggestions. When moving from Testrunner to Testopia we brought many of the field names forward to prevent confusion. You make an excellent point though.
I am partial to "Expected Outcomes" or "Expected Results". Are there any other suggestions.

(In reply to comment #1) > I am partial to "Expected Outcomes" or "Expected Results". Are there any other > suggestions.
I vote for "Expected Results"

(In reply to comment #2) > (In reply to comment #1) > > I am partial to "Expected Outcomes" or "Expected Results". Are there any other > > suggestions. > > I vote for "Expected Results" >
I vote for "Expected Results" as well.
Fixed Chaneged to Expected Results.

bug.short_desc: Filtering by component can yield duplicate results

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.4) Gecko/20070515 Firefox/2.0.0.4 Build Identifier: 1.2
If a test case is associated to more than one component, it will be returned multiple times when filtering by more than one of those components. For instance, assume we have three components (C1, C3 and C3). Now let's assume we have a test run that includes the following test cases with their associated components in brackets...
TC1 (C1) TC2 (C1 and C2) TC3 (C3) TC4 (C2 and C3)
In the test run search, we choose to filter by component and select both C1 and C2, meaning we want all test cases that are associated to C1 and/or C2. We would therefore expect to get the following list returned...
TC1 TC2 TC4
Instead we get the following...
TC1 TC2 TC2 TC4
The second result is duplicated because it is associated to both components that have been queried (likely a missing DISTINCT in the sql). The test case count at the bottom becomes inaccurate because counts them separately. In our previous example, it would say that there are 4 test cases that match our filtering criteria in the current test run, when in truth there are only three.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Associate five different components to a test case 2. Create a test run that includes this test case 3. In the test run view, expand the Filter section 4. Select three of the five components associated to the TC in Step 1 and click the Filter button. Actual Results:
The same test case run is listed three times and the test case count at the bottom of the table says "3 test cases found", when in truth there's only one.
Expected Results:
The test case run is listed only once. The count at the bottom says "1 test case found".
Note that clicking on the "Case ID" heading can be used as a temporary workaround due to bug 384212 (as long as you don't have a version where it's already fixed).
Fixed

"-1 is not a valid test plan identifier"

bug.short_desc: Request for configurable "Read-only" dashboard view that doesn't require log in

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 6.0; SLCC1; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; Media Center PC 5.0; .NET CLR 3.0.04506; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; InfoPath.2; .NET CLR 3.5.21022; OfficeLiveConnector.1.0) Build Identifier: 2.0
I've used QualityCenter, am using TestLink, and have some smaller open source test case managment systems. One useful feature, that at my last company we implemented via a custom solution, is a read-only dashboard that executives and management can hit with a web page without having to login.
Is there an inherently compelling reason (other than the time to create it) that one would not want this feature? I can't think on one, but maybe there is. Anyways, I'd like to publish html links to product test case execution and project status that does not require a login.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Login to to testopia and check out the dashboard. Actual Results: Testtopia (and other TC managment systems I've used), require a login for dashboard or reporting views.
Expected Results: I'd like a report or dashboard view for managers and executives that is read-only and does not require a login. Thanks!

Greg, I agree with Sean. This prevents us from pasting URLs to new QA testers and other Bugzilla developers to see our progress in QA. They have no way to see the progress bar when testing a new release. Could you put this bug high in your TODO list, please?

Security policy is always a tricky subject. The underlying principals around Testopia's enforcement of login requirement is that test data is often forward looking and therefore more private than defect data.
What kind of dashboards are you looking for? The current dashboard reports all use permission data in the query which means just removing the login requirement will not work since any dashboard an outsider viewed would be blank. Testopia allows granular control of rights at the Bugzilla group and Test plan levels.
A change like this would require a fundamental shift in Testopia's search and reporting system not to mention, security policy.

From a QA point of view, all I'm interested in is that external people can view a progress bar showing how far we are with QA (with green/orange/red colors so that they can also know if everything is going well or not), and on the right of the progress bar a numerical indicator like 18/29 (62%) to have an absolute scale. Everything else could be hidden. There is no security implication at all here, I think.

bug.short_desc: Test Case history is not created for Create, Action/Expected, or Setup/Break down updated

assigned_to.name: Nobody; OK to take it and work on it

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.14) Gecko/20080404 Firefox/2.0.0.14 Build Identifier: Testopia Version 2.0-RC2 for (Bugzilla 3.0.x)
Test Case history doesn't seem to be tracking all test case changes.
This is important because in some QA organizations there is a requirement for test cases to be maintained strictly accorded to requirements in which an change to the test case should be traceable to the person who edited. An in fact this is just good information to have should someone mistakenly update a procedure and removed important steps.
The other more profound reason test case history is required is when a test case is changed from build to build to accommodate new feature behavior in the form of a different action or expectation. If Test Run always references the latest version of a given test case then when changes are made to the referenced test case it will also changes the test cases in older runs. This is misleading because the Test Case in the older runs now reflect the new action or expectation when they really should preserve what the action was when that build was tested.
The other way around this is to create a new Test Case each time the procedure changes but this causes all of the history to be lost and create many instances of the same test. It also breaks the ability for sophisticated reporting to be gotten. A very useful report that is used for Risk Assessment to determine the readiness or risk of releasing using aggregated data across build by looking back at the last N builds and see when the last time the test was run, passed or failed. To do this though you need to have a mean of having a consent reference to a Test Case throughout it's history.
Test Runs should really link to versions of a Test Case rather than a single Test Case reference so that test cases referenced in older runs are not affected when a test case is changed.
Another reason why you want to preserve this information in a Run is because there are occasions when a development line is determined to be to unstable or a branch in made at an earlier build.
What can happen when a destabilizing feature is added is that there is a decision to snap back to a previous build to release it instead. If the test case where all change to match the feature that is now removed then there is no way to just go back to the test case in the state they were before the reverted change. Retesting without the destabilizing feature and only a few cherry picked features many be required. However if the old runs still point to the old version of the test then you would just clone the run and start testing again.
Branching at older build points commonly occurs too the current branch many have too many new and changed features for a specific project so an older build is selected as a branch candidate. Again there is a need to know exact what the actions in the old test cases used to do, this cause the same problem mentioned above.
That information could be derived from the test_case_activity table maybe.
So there a many real world reasons why test runs need to point to versions of the same test while maintaining reporting requirements that allow the same test to be consistently queried through the build history of a branch.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: Reproduction Procedures: 1. Select create a new test case. 2. Enter a summary line 3. In Action Tab enter: 1.Action Create 4. In Expected Result Tab enter: 1. Expected Create 5. Select anything for other required field and leave defaults on remaining fields 6. Submit 7. Select yes to go the test case 8. Click history An entry is not made for the creation of the test? 9. Select default tester and enter a valid tester name 10. Click history An entry for this change was made as expected 11. Now click Action/Expected Result tab 12. In Action Tab add: 2.Action Update 13. In Expected Result Tab add: 2. Expected Update 14. Click history An entry is not made for the update of the test? Actual Results: Above comment states results
Created an attachment (id=327027) Report Description

Created an attachment (id=327028) Risk Assessment Report Example
This is an example of how Test run history on Test Cases can be used to aggregate many runs into a "State of Test" as any given time. It shows areas of the test plan that pose the greatest risk or exposure at the moment. It allows QA managers to better deploy resources into areas that need attention and it shows release teams the current state of test cover at a glance.
Created an attachment (id=327029) Help balloon for the attached report

Changes to the large text fields are tracked, but they are tracked separately. If you click the Action/Expected Results tab you will notice a dropdown and a button that says View Version. You ca review any previous version of the text that way.
I can buy the argument that a record of the change should also be displayed in the activity tab. This would be pretty trivial. There is much more that can be done to this area though. See bug 340461 for example.
What tool is used to generate these reports?

Thanks for the response, the reports that I attached are created by myself. I have been building my own test result management tools for over a decade now because there really hasn't been anything out in the open source community worth building upon that I was aware of, until now. My tool is called Kingpin and it has been custom tailored to each company I've worked for. It is primarily for automated testing but it also supports manual result tracking and reporting. It has Perl based agents that run on test beds (Windows or Linux) that generate the test cases automatically as new ones are found from the automation source code, they run the tests, collect the data and create runs with the newly generated results. The reports you see will display both manual and automated results.
I really like what I have seen so far with Testopia and have started an internal movement here to evaluate is as a replacement for mine and other tools we use. It would be interesting to be able to contribute to the this effort too if possible. Is there a better way to communicate about this possibility?

(In reply to comment #5)
> I really like what I have seen so far with Testopia and have started an > internal movement here to evaluate is as a replacement for mine and other tools > we use. It would be interesting to be able to contribute to the this effort too > if possible.
Glad to hear it is helpful.
>Is there a better way to communicate about this possibility?
The project home page at http://www.mozilla.org/projects/testopia lists a number of contact methods. I am usually in IRC for example or there is always the mailing list.
I can always use help in the area of reporting. Feel free to mess around and post patches. In general we follow the Bugzilla contributing guidelines, which means if you would like to submit something, log a bug, attach a patch and request review on that patch from me.
Feel free to contact me with questions, or you can post them here if they are relevant to this bug.

bug.short_desc: RFE: To have test runs point to the version of the test case used when the run was created

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.15) Gecko/20080623 Firefox/2.0.0.15 Build Identifier:
It would be very useful for the test runs to point the the exact version of the test case used when the run was created instead of the latest version. It would nice to have this feature configurable for those who may not need this feature too.
Explanation: On development projects of any length a test case may typically adapt to changes in the product build by build. Early in the project a test case might reflect the initial behavior of the feature. In the later part of the project if may have a very different Action/Expectation etc.
There are times when the question arises, why didn't we test this or how was this tested on this run. See Bug 442145 for more examples of the uses of using Test Run history. Currently the Test Case data displayed for any and all runs pointing to the same test case will also point to the latest version only. If some of the runs were created before the current version of the Test Case the data that shows what steps (Action) for example that were used for testing would be wrong. See 'Steps to Reproduce' to better understand the issue.
It would be more accurate and useful if the runs could also store the version of the test case used when the run was created and allow this to be a configurable feature.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create Test Cases 1-3 like: 1. Step 1 2. Step 2 3. Step 3 2. Create a Test Plan using these Test Cases 3. Create a Test Run using the Test Plan - Let's pretend that was done on the very first build. Let's call it Run 1 for our example. - In the Run view Test Case 1 and view the Action text, as expected there is no change to what we initially entered. 4. Change test cases 1 in the Test Plan. Let's pretend that this is 40 builds later in response to a feature change. - Delete steps 2-3 and add something like this to the Action: "Description of what to look for.. blah blah blah" 5. Create a new Test Run - pretend it is Run 40. - View the Test Case and it reflect the latest version as expected
The issue occurs from this point: Now go back to Run 1, view the Test Run again and then select Test Case 1
What we really should see is the version of the Test Case that was used at the time that this Test Run was created however it shows the current Test Case Action text which was not used during this run.
We should see the Action as: 1. Step 1 2. Step 2 3. Step 3
But instead we see the Action as: 1. Step 1 Description of what to look for.. blah blah blah"
Compound this with thousand of tests, hundreds of run and the historical usefulness of the run data because unreliable.
I've provided details on how this data is used in real world scenarios in bug: 442145
Actual Results: We should see the Action as: 1. Step 1 2. Step 2 3. Step 3
Expected Results: But instead we see the Action as: 1. Step 1 Description of what to look for.. blah blah blah"

(From update of attachment 391654) This is looking much better. There are a few nit picks below that are easily fixed.
>- $row->{'changed'} = format_time($row->{'changed'}, TIME_FORMAT);
This is not a change you made. What this removal of a line means is that you are not modifying an updated copy of the file. When you modify a file for a patch, be sure that the copy you are modifying is the latest version available. If I were to apply this patch unchanged, it would remove several fixes that I have checked in.
>+# MAParent modification start >+ my $plan = Bugzilla::Testopia::TestPlan->new($plan_ids[0]); >+ $obj->{'plan_name'} = $plan->name; >+# MAParent modification end
Rather than instantiate a new copy of a TestPlan object, why not just reuse the existing one:
$obj->{'plan_name'} = ${$self->plans}[0]->name;
Also: Rather than add comments to where you have modified the code, for the version you submit for the patch, just place your name and email at the top in the "Contributors" section. Otherwise the files tend to get very cluttered really quickly. You are of course welcome to keep these in your version, but once it becomes part of the code base, it is part of the code base and you don't need to keep track of your modifications.
>+//MAParent modification Start >+ {header: "Plan", width: 40, sortable: true, dataIndex: 'plan_id', hidden: true, renderer: tutil.plan_link, >+ groupRenderer: function(value,u,record){return value + '; "' + record.get('plan_name') + '"';}}, >+//MAParent modification End
Same rule applies here, just put your name at the top. There is a minor nit in the naming of the variables here. By convention we use v and r to represent value and record in these closures since it reduces the character count and helps keep conformity. I also prefer a ':' instead of a ';' after the plan id.
Otherwise, great job!

The access controls are at the plan level, and they control the plan and all its subordinate objects (runs, cases, and case runs).

Okay.

This code was a project that Luis Velazquez and I worked on this summer. It uses a wrapper package that uses the existing environment package and makes a machine. The idea is that the Machine uses an environment and all extra information goes to the test_machines table (which only has a location at this moment). Since the machine is where any test may run, we removed the product attachment using product 0. We limited the environment editor to a nested depth of 2 (machine name -> category -> element since this is a "better" model of a machine) instead of the huge amount of flexibility that was in place originally.

We began implementing a search, but do not have it finished with this patch. The plan is to have archive tables (test_machine_(category|element)_archive) and search them for test runs that ran on specific elements and anything related or that can be derived.
A planned and unimplemented feature was to have a network card database that links the Network card element to a table that contained network info (ip, subnet, etc). This would have both a machine/environment_id and an element_id so that the mapping is made through this table with all the extra information necessary for the cards that is not generic (for use with manual creation using the environment editor b/c global items (network cards) can be used on more than 1 machine and have different information)
This is the summary of the changes made, and hope there is something useful in our contribution.

Suppose I am developing test cases using the New Case functionality. Generally speaking, there is a lot of repetition involved in writing test cases, particularly when shooting for good coverage. Let's face it, writing a comprehensive set of test cases is tedious, and becomes an exercise in cut and paste and tweak.
Currently with the dojo editing stuff, if you try to be clever and use the back button to go back and re-edit and re-submit a modified test case, you find that most of the fields are reset to empty. So you end up having to enter all those values again. sigh.

bug.short_desc: for portability, tr_install.pl should use Text::Patch instead of patch command

assigned_to.name: Nobody's working on this, feel free to take it

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; de; rv:1.8.0.5) Gecko/20060816 Firefox/1.5.0.5 Build Identifier: testopia-1.1.3
Hi,
I'm trying to set up Bugzilla 2.22.1 + Testopia 1.1.3 on a FreeBSD system. tr_install.pl will fail in three places, since it is assumeing a newer patch version.
1. The test for 'patch -v' fails, as the FreeBSD version prints a single line on STDERR. Simple workaround for this is to use 'patch -v 2>&1' instead.
2. The second bumper is the --dry-run option. FreeBSD patch uses -C for this.
3. The actual patching will fail, too. There is no -z option on FreeBSD's patch and -b is different
please refer to the manpage, to see which options do apply: http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=patch
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Install FreeBSD 6.2 2. Try to install Testopia

We have no freebsd machines to test with.
If you're willing and able, please attach a tr_install fix for freebsd that doesn't break other operating systems. If not, we'll need to leave this bug open for someone else to pick up.

Due to time constraints I can't work on a truly portable solution, so let this be a FYI for other FreeBSD users trying to install Bugzilla/Testopia
Since I need to patch the install script on the fly, I used the following sed(1) command. This should make it work on pretty much every FreeBSD-Installation out there:
sed -e 's/patchPath -v`/patchPath -v 2>\&1`/' \ -e 's/patchPath -s -l --dry-run -bp 2/patchPath --quiet -l -C -p2/' \ -e 's/patchPath -s -l -z .orig -bp 2/patchPath --quiet -l -p2/' \ tr_install.pl.orig > tr_install.pl
This will of course break Linux systems, as the --dry-run/-C flags conflict and -b has a different meaning. Ideally, you could use a Perlmodule 'Patch', that can provide a truly portable way of patching the bugzilla source. This would also remove the need to check for a Win32 patch.exe. (I don't know if such a module exists)
In other news: Testopia, as installed by me, required two additional perl modules to work. These modules are not installed along the perl-5.8.8 port I'm using, nor does testopia check for their existance! You should at least document them in the manual as requirements ... darn! I see that Text::Diff is actually mentiond there, but the JSON module is not listed.

(In reply to comment #2)
> In other news: Testopia, as installed by me, required two additional perl > modules to work. These modules are not installed along the perl-5.8.8 port I'm > using, nor does testopia check for their existance! You should at least > document them in the manual as requirements ... darn! I see that Text::Diff is > actually mentiond there, but the JSON module is not listed.
I agree -- the manual is out of date -- sigh.
I'm updating http://wiki.mozilla.org/Testopia:README#Requirements to mention these perl modules.
Both Text::Diff and JSON are enforced as requirements in the (patched) checksetup.pl. According to http://wiki.mozilla.org/Testopia:README#Installation you're supposed to run checksetup after tr_install.
Your suggestion to use http://search.cpan.org/~cade/Text-Patch-1.2/Patch.pm is excellent, btw.
tr_install no longer exists (as of Testopia 1.3).

Amen Brother. :)
Originally, I had set out to do just that, and some day I hope to build in such capability. The idea was to have a full suite of Requirements/Tests/Bugs in one system. We now have the Test suite plugin (Testopia) and I still hope to get to the requirements plugin some day, but I doubt it will happen soon.

Hey Gang! I am interested in collaborating on Testopia, and it seems to align pretty closely with something I've wanted for a lot of years. I bought the domain name "openRequirements.org" about 5 years ago with the intent of creating a requirements engineering system (which would support requirements definition as well as verification/testing.) I have some notes and thoughts on the topic, but it is not spec'd out formally at this time. Please contact me if you want to brainstorm moving Testopia in this direction.

bug.short_desc: Cannot export/import a test plan in testopia

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; GTB5; InfoPath.1; .NET CLR 2.0.50727) Build Identifier:
At the moment, we are allowed to export/import test cases, but not test plans. A test plan includes more information/data and also includes test cases. Here's an example of the table of contents that may be included in a test plan.
TABLE OF CONTENTS SYSTEM TEST PLAN 1 1 INTRODUCTION 4 1.1 OVERVIEW 4 1.2 PURPOSE 4 2 LIST OF ACRONYMS 5 3 TEST STRATEGY 6 3.1 REQUIREMENTS CLASSIFICATION 7 4 DEFICIENCY REPORTING & TRACEABILITY 8 4.1 DEFICIENCY REPORTING 8 4.2 DEFICIENCY TRACEABILITY 8 5 FUNCTIONAL TESTING 9 5.1 GENERAL CONFIGURATION TEST CASE 9 5.2 SYSTEM TEST CASE 10 5.3 ETC.....
Reproducible: Always

Expected Results: Should be able to export a test plan.
Have a user configurable test plan template and being able to export the test plan.

Ah, I suspect this is actually a Testopia problem, because Testopia uses UNSIGNED columns and Bugzilla doesn't. See:
http://forums.devarticles.com/mysql-development-50/mysql-foreign-key-problem-errno-150t-7704.html
My suspicion is that somehow one of your columns became UNSIGNED where it shouldn't be. Could I see the output from MySQL of:
DESC namedqueries_link_in_footer;

Field Type Null Key Default Extra namedquery_id mediumint(9) NO PRI 0 user_id mediumint(9) NO PRI 0

Hrm, strange. Could I see:
DESC namedqueries;

Database: bugsandbox Generation Time: Dec 07, 2007 at 01:02 PM SQL query: DESC namedqueries;
Rows: 5 Field Type Null Key Default Extra userid mediumint(9) NO MUL 0 name varchar(64) NO query mediumtext NO query_type tinyint(4) NO 0 id mediumint(8) unsigned NO PRI NULL auto_increment

(In reply to comment #8) > id mediumint(8) unsigned NO PRI NULL auto_increment
That's your problem. Either Bugzilla will have to move to using unsigned ints for serial types, or Testopia will have to stop using them.

Max:
Bugzilla and Testopia have co-existed in the past despite this inconsistency. Do you know what's different now?

(In reply to comment #10) > Bugzilla and Testopia have co-existed in the past despite this inconsistency. > Do you know what's different now?
Bugzilla 3.1.x changed to InnoDB and introduced referential integrity.
is there a work-around?

(In reply to comment #12) > is there a work-around?
If you alter the namedqueries.id column to not be unsigned, that would probably work around it for now. But you're likely to run into other problems.
Also remember that Testopia is tied to particular versions of Bugzilla, and you are upgrading to a version of Bugzilla that is not supported by the version of Testopia you are running.

Testopia does not modify the namedqueries table so I don't understand why this is a Testopia issue. It is true that other references from Testopia tables to bugzilla tables might present issues, but I believe for the most part, no foreign keys into Bugzilla are unsigned. Only Testopia ID's are unsigned.

Since 1.1 is the first version that will support Pg, as far as I know, there aren't any upgrade problems, so you don't have to worry about telling people "you can only upgrade from this version." Pg users don't need to upgrade.

Apparently the names of indexes are global in PostgreSQL. So this bug is caused by fielddefs and test_fielddefs both having an index named fielddefs_name_idx.
(In MySQL, the name of an index needs to be unique only within a table.)
I just verified that fielddefs_name_idx is the only index with this problem.

bug.short_desc: User Lookup fields are missing in IE7

long_desc.thetext: User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322) Build Identifier: IE7 Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. 2. 3. Actual Results: no combo Expected Results: there should be a combo
Created an attachment (id=349929) bugs

For some reason all the User Lookup fields (found here and other places throughout Testopia) are not appearing in IE7. Can you tell me if they were there before? Did you recently upgrade? I have tried it on IE 7 going back to prior versions and it does not seem to make a difference. I am guessing this is caused by an update to IE itself.
I will need to raise this issue with the makers of Extjs. In the meantime, there is a workaround:
1. Edit the testopia/js/util.js file in your installation. 2. Find the section under UserLookup 3. Look for the line that reads: hideTrigger: true, 4. Change it to read: hideTrigger: false, 5. Go to the bugzilla parameters page and under the Testopia tab, change the testopia-debug parameter to "Developer"
This seems to make the box appear.
It seems there is a fix available, see https://extjs.com/forum/showthread.php?t=51457 and http://extjs.com/forum/showthread.php?p=204817

It works. This is the first time i use Testopia. So I don't konow whether "they were there before?". I find Testopia works better and quicker on FireFox3.0 than it on IE7.0. so I change to use FF3.0. Thanks a lot.

I have applied the fix mentioned above in Testopia code.
